results.content:
From zero to Spring boot hero. Having used Spring boot before, this was good for getting an understanding of the internals. 

The course if comprehensive and extends beyond microservices and touches on tools within the ecosystem like Eureka, Zuul, Zipkin and more

The content was well thought out and paced and that allowed me to follow and build concepts and practical understanding with hands-on exercises. As a technical manager looking to get more acquainted with Java, Spring and microservices again the course was able to deliver. 

It's good for beginners all the way to experienced developers

results.content:
I found the course very useful and enlightning. I find very adecuate to start building a REST service and then move on to microservices architectures. It helps a lot in undertanding the different pieces of the final puzzle.

But I think that given the fast pace springboot and spring cloud are evolving, some parts of the course should be updated, as dependencies change names, or are splitted, or partially merged, and so on; just as an example: I used version 2.0.0.RELEASE of springboot and Finchley.M8 of spring cloud and found serious problems running the exercises involving the Zipkin server (in fact, I ended up using the zipkin server in openzipkin github repository in order to be able to trace the requests of the other microservices)

As a final suggestion, I'd like to be included in the course any exercise related to running the microservices in containers, using docker/kubernetes.

Best regards,
results.content_html:
I found the course very useful and enlightning. I find very adecuate to start building a REST service and then move on to microservices architectures. It helps a lot in undertanding the different pieces of the final puzzle.

But I think that given the fast pace springboot and spring cloud are evolving, some parts of the course should be updated, as dependencies change names, or are splitted, or partially merged, and so on; just as an example: I used version 2.0.0.RELEASE of springboot and Finchley.M8 of spring cloud and found serious problems running the exercises involving the Zipkin server (in fact, I ended up using the zipkin server in openzipkin github repository in order to be able to trace the requests of the other microservices)

As a final suggestion, I'd like to be included in the course any exercise related to running the microservices in containers, using docker/kubernetes.

Best regards,

results.content:
The course is very helpful and the instructor has done a great job explaining in-depth concepts  in an easy to understand manner. The instructor is very knowledgeable and a gifted teacher. After finishing up the course I have a got far better understanding of Spring and Microservices. 
I like the way the course is structured and how the instructor has touched on topics that are very relevant to the course but they are not restricted to Microservices or Spring Cloud.

I'm very thankful to Ranga for making this course and I look forward to learning more from you!

Thanks again.

results.content:
This course laid a strong foundation for me to dive deep into microservice-architecture and to develop microservices.

I've been working in microservices projects which were generated by JHipster and I wanted to understand how the components like Spring cloud, Eureka, zuul and ribbon works, with this course I got clear understanding and the use and necessity of these components.

It would have been be good if more explanation, uses and examples were added to Zuul gateway API, Sleuth, Distributed tracing and Hystrix because nearly 4 hours of content is on RESTful web services but we only created a simple get request in the microservices section, this time could be used in explaining in-depth functionality of the microservices components.

I like the instructor's approach:
Instructor starts coding while recording, this approach works for me, I watch the video, try to remember the steps and at the end of video I code. I found many instructors with the approach I-copy-paste-code-and-explain-it-for-you, which did not work and off-putting for me.

It's good that GitHub repo details are provided which has all the source code and instructions but it would be excellent if the instructor could provide PDF slides with definitions, uses of individual components of microservices, images to illustrate and code samples. It would be really helpful in the future to refresh the memory.

This course is really helpful. Thank you.

results.content:
This explanation of web services has been presented in a rather confusing way. I accept that purpose of webservice is interoperability and communication between servers ignoring the technology in the back-end. But the simple explanation should be :    1) A graphic showing Communication between  Server (web Server) to UI Client (Browser) is via HTML + Some Data embedded in HTML          2) A graphic showing - But the servers dont understand HTML they can only communicate with data that is where webservices come into picture. 

Webservices are of Two types : SOAP based webservices (designed specifically for Server to Server communication : Uses specialized Protocols for communication over web), The medium is always XML, Requires a contract for understanding terminology therefore with SOAP based webservices if a Server A and B are both communicating with Server C they require different contracts, Could be stateful  
RESTFul webservices : technology agnostic (does not even know which technology requesting data), Communicates over simple HTTP protocol (No need for specialized protocols) , Media could be XML, HTML, JSON, XLS... , No contracts required, Stateless so no contract required and it is the responsibility of requesting server to map and use the response as per REST documentation

results.content:
Good examples. Overall very good course, well paced. Really recommend it.

Having said that, some comments I thought may be helpful to the author:

1. I am an advanced learner, the first few sessions were not interesting such as - Comparing ReST and SOAP. What is REST etc. IMHO I guess someone learning Spring Boot will have a decent experience with Spring and HTTP fundamentals. I could be wrong here (I have never authored a course :))

2. This is my personal suggestion, may not be applicable to others. The course could have been structured into themes such as Request Processing, Exception Handling, Content Negotiation rather than as steps 1 - 37. They are there in the sessions headings, but categorising may have been a better way or organising the course.

I am really dispaointed with this course. Part about REST was cursory. Part about Microservices was a disaster.
1) the lectures and the structrure of the course is very chaotic. Some parts of the course are outdated but still included.
2) After finishing the course I still do not know what is the purpose of the Microservices. I know some tools but I do not know when and WHY should I use them.
3) Microservices is only a tiny bit of the whole course
4) you do not know when to follow your teacher. Some projects are created only for one lecture, some stay with you for a longer period.
5) part about Kubernetes is extremely more difficult than the rest of the course (basics)
I highky recommend to choose another course on this topic

results.content:
Recommended for those starting with Spring Development, but NOT recommended for those already familiar with Spring looking to get started with Spring Cloud. The latter part of the course is mostly just basic theory and adding dependencies without actually going in detail through the functionalities and alternatives for the components being discusses. Also a bit outdated, so you might have to lookup how to do the things being taught today w.r.t. dependencies, properties etc. (Although they do try to be up to date with text banners on videos). Also totally skips testing, which was really disappointing. Suggestions for creators:
- Add docs/ links in each spring cloud component listing features in more detail (Currently only single basic functionality is shown)
- Include testing
results.content_html:

results.content:
After going through a bunch of tutorials and other courses (on udemy and elsewhere), this is probably the best hands-on microservices course that available anywhere.

The instructor is very clear, the explanations are detailed enough and the pace of the course is great. 

My only critique of this course is that even though the intro section on REST services was great, its concepts weren't fully used in the microservices section.
Also, as everyone has said, it would've been great to see some implementation of spring security with oauth2 (and JWT).
results.content_html:
After going through a bunch of tutorials and other courses (on udemy and elsewhere), this is probably the best hands-on microservices course that available anywhere.

The instructor is very clear, the explanations are detailed enough and the pace of the course is great.

My only critique of this course is that even though the intro section on REST services was great, its concepts weren't fully used in the microservices section.
Also, as everyone has said, it would've been great to see some implementation of spring security with oauth2 (and JWT).

results.content:
I had actually bought this course and requested refund earlier as I knew almost everything in this course. I was hoping for real world examples on how CRUD ops are performed and communication takes places between various services when the data sources are diversified. Was also hoping for some sections on deployment using containerization and orchestration using something like Kubernetes or alternates. If the author can enhance the course a little bit further, it would be a perfect course.

I decided to re-purchase because I had already watched the crucial sections, also because the course itself is a good reference point instead of google searches and provides good examples for current Spring Cloud/ Netflix stack.

results.content: I took this course so as to gain a better understanding of working with micro-services. The course far exceeded my expectations. I had some understanding of working with micro services. The instructor broke down the material so that I could examine the pieces I needed. Additionally, there was a ramp-up section so that I could be familiar with how the instructor presents the material and know that I could start a later section without missing something. The course is well thought out, presented, and provides a lot of useful material and resources for current learning and knowing how to move forward with micro services. Highly recommend!

results.content:
The journey throughout this series of spring boot was wonderful. During the series I also got my hands dirty with a lot of practice and came up with designing an eCommerce sample application using microservice architecture style, there I have tried to implement all the components of spring cloud discussed in the series. The interesting part is I got to understand the complete picture of where to use which component and why they were introduced. this helped me to get a lot of understanding of the microservice-based distributed system architecture till some extend.  The only reason I am giving 4.5 stars because some topics I believe are under-taught like Hystrix and some were missing like circuit breaker pattern, distributed session/global tokens, otherwise, all were well explained with practice. 
At the end I want to thank Mr. Ranga for this wonderful well-structured series of spring boot microservice course, the way he structured the course and provide all from ships to needles is remarkable. Well done!! and keep it up.
results.content_html:
The journey throughout this series of spring boot was wonderful. During the series I also got my hands dirty with a lot of practice and came up with designing an eCommerce sample application using microservice architecture style, there I have tried to implement all the components of spring cloud discussed in the series. The interesting part is I got to understand the complete picture of where to use which component and why they were introduced. this helped me to get a lot of understanding of the microservice-based distributed system architecture till some extend. The only reason I am giving 4.5 stars because some topics I believe are under-taught like Hystrix and some were missing like circuit breaker pattern, distributed session/global tokens, otherwise, all were well explained with practice.
At the end I want to thank Mr. Ranga for this wonderful well-structured series of spring boot microservice course, the way he structured the course and provide all from ships to needles is remarkable. Well done!! and keep it up.

results.content:
The Person (Ranga) giving this course, is good with the technical concepts. However a couple of important observations:
1) It would do a world of good, If Ranga comes on screen introduces himself, talk about his professional experiences, his company 'in28minutes' et al. An on screen presence would do a world of good to this course.

2) Ranga needs to improve his tone and modulation quite a bit. The tone and modulation **might** sound familiar to Indian students, however for a student from a different geography, it might be tough to catch up.

3) It is important to a proper conclusion to the course and then move on to the next course. Ranga's "bye bye" at the end of the course seems as if he is in a hurry. Slow down a bit!
Technically of course, I am beginning to like the course. It is good so far.

results.content: Although the course seems just a tiny bit outdated I got a really good overview what microservices are and how you would use them in the real world. Ranga does a great job explaining complicated concepts with small examples that you can implement really easily. Additionally, he walks you through all the steps necessary to install additional software and provides troubleshooting guides in case you get stuck at some point. Altogether a great course which I would recommend everyone who wants/needs to learn about microservices.

results.content:
The first part of the course explaining how to build simple REST services and how to use JPA was a bit boring and took too much time. My expectation is that this is a prerequisite for building microservices. Also, for the simplicity of the demo, some bad practices were presented and it wasn't mentioned that they should be avoided. If you are absolutely novice to the Spring and need 4h of tutorials to build a simple REST service + JPA persistence then things like proper constructor DI, DTOs and separation of concerns between the layers should be explained.
However, the second part of the course is worth the time and money invested. The author provides simple and understandable examples for a variety of technologies related to microservices best practices. It is an amazing video tutorial. Awesome!

If you are absolutely novice to the Spring and need 4h of tutorials to build a simple REST service + JPA persistence then things like proper constructor DI, DTOs and separation of concerns between the layers should be explained.
However, the second part of the course is worth the time and money invested. The author provides simple and understandable examples for a variety of technologies related to microservices best practices. It is an amazing video tutorial. Awesome!

You wouldn't be able to deploy any real world project after this course.

Meet all the expectations. All the technologies that were introduced are things that I have came across through my work. I would recommend this course for anyone who is not really beginner in term of development but maybe (beginner in) getting to know Spring. The course can be overwhelming for people who wants to learn programming for example or to learn web development.

The second comment is that you repeat what you said at the closing of the previous video in the new video, that was a bit too much for me.

With all of what said, I would like to say "Thank you" and best of luck with other courses.

results.content:
Not my first course with Ranga, wont be my last. 
This is the ONLY course out there that covers SO MUCH all in one place.
Ranga starts with a RESTful spring boot application, moving to spring cloud and the various tools in place, and then covers docker and kubernetes specific to a spring boot project and even deploying it to a cloud provider. Which is CRAZY good content for just 1 course. There is literally no other course out there like this that gives you a great overview and enough hands on to understand alllll the concepts of Microservices, spring cloud, docker & k8s & cloud. 

Love your work ranga. thank you !

results.content:
Good for beginners, professionals stay away.

I'm a professional software developer with 3 years of experience. I needed to learn Spring Boot for my new job, and I figured I would try an online course to do so. Overall, I felt like the course went way too slowly and didn't go deeply into any of the topics it covered. Many of the videos probably could have been compressed and the topics could have been covered much faster. For example, I think this guide on the spring website (https://spring.io/guides/tutorials/rest/) covers pretty much everything the first 4 hour section of the course covers and in more depth. I got about halfway through the micro-services v2 section before giving up. If you are experienced, the time invested in working through this course would be better served on other learning materials.

I'm giving this 4 stars instead of a lower rating just because I don't think I'm the intended audience of this course. Overall, the course writers clearly put a ton of effort into making it, with in depth debugging guides and plenty of example code. This would probably be a fantastic resource for beginners because of how much effort is put into solving errors and keeping you in the rails. However, some of the code written uses some vaguely bad practices. The example that first comes to mind is that at one point the teacher explicitly sets the port of the service through a config file. When explaining how to run multiple services such that each is on a different port, he says to override the config file by providing a different port as a command line argument. He could have just as easily shown setting the port in the config file through an environment variable and passed the environment variable to the application through the runtime configuration in almost the same way he passed the command line argument. I noticed a few similar issues throughout the course.
results.content_html:

results.content:
The course is good, it covered lot of stuffs about Microservices and various spring libraries that we can use to build Microservices pretty quickly. Overall it is a very good course for somebody who wants to get started with Microservices. 

I would have liked to see the instructor covering event driven architecture for Microservices.  There is always the risk that one Microservice that depends another one may not be available so I am hearing that communication using events is a better approach than direct communication. 

Also I would have liked the instructor to talk about managing transactions when multiple Microservices are involved to complete the request.

results.content:
This course provides a good introduction to spring cloud and to the world of microservices. But I feel it doesn't cover enough ground to call itself - "Master microservices with Spring boot and Spring cloud". Below are some of the problems:
- It doesn't talk about problems with data management and the available solutions to address these problems. All the services being developed in the examples of this course are read services which do not provide the challenges with transaction management. 
- There is no mention of any security implementations in the microservices or in the API gateway.
- Also, it would help if at least a diagram is made available explaining the set up of these components especially the spring cloud config server in the production environment. Where would this service be hosted. Do we have a single instance (or cluster of instances) holding the config for all the environments? In that case, in which environment should this instance be deployed? Production?
I hope at least the above mentioned questions are answered in the course in the form of updates and I guess it increases the value of the course immensely.
results.content_html:
This course provides a good introduction to spring cloud and to the world of microservices. But I feel it doesn't cover enough ground to call itself - "Master microservices with Spring boot and Spring cloud". Below are some of the problems:
- It doesn't talk about problems with data management and the available solutions to address these problems. All the services being developed in the examples of this course are read services which do not provide the challenges with transaction management.
- There is no mention of any security implementations in the microservices or in the API gateway.
- Also, it would help if at least a diagram is made available explaining the set up of these components especially the spring cloud config server in the production environment. Where would this service be hosted. Do we have a single instance (or cluster of instances) holding the config for all the environments? In that case, in which environment should this instance be deployed? Production?
I hope at least the above mentioned questions are answered in the course in the form of updates and I guess it increases the value of the course immensely.

results.content:
The course is very good for learning Spring Boot framework and related components required to support it. I would like to suggest few suggestions regarding this course.
1. The hands on example should be updated to be compatible with latest spring boot framework and Java. (Once in every six month should be fine.) The reason is user doing hands-on is facing lot of issues in latest framework and spending hours to resolve the problems.
2. Few concepts should be explained by presenting diagrams. (Preferably with small animation)

Thanks and regards.
results.content_html:

results.content:
This would have been a good course, however, the creators have focused on creating multiple courses - with duplicate content.

So while this course *looks* like it covers SOAP that's actually because they duplicated the same lectures as their SOAP course into this course too.

Courses from this provider looked to me to have about one unique section and the rest was duplicate content.

Summary: A good overview but expect to have limited depth;  one/two sections of value - any more depth than that and the content would be broken out into a new course. 

There is a *lot* more depth (though less simplified introduction) in some of the other courses on the same topic. This course basically covers making a REST service - there are 100 tutorial online on doing that. Needs way more content.

results.content:
This course consists of the most used features in developing web services with Spring Boot. I work primarily on the front-end at my current job and have seen a lot of the class methods that he overrides or uses directly, but haven't had time to dig into what's actually going on.
 I am only 22% on the way through the course an have learned more than any other Spring course I have purchased. Mostly, because other courses spend a lot of time with the basics and are slow to move to enterprise-level intricacies such as, application-wide exception handling and customizing responses for failed validation.
I am excited about continuing the rest of the course and would recommend it to anyone that desires a thorough explanation of the main features used in enterprise application development with Spring Boot.
results.content_html:

results.content: Really good course... The instructor covered Spring Boot and Spring Cloud  pretty well. He also covered a fair bit of Netflix OSS, which was awesome.

results.content:
I like the way the instructor took us through the wide spectrum of Spring Boot and especially Spring Cloud. However, there are two aspects that would have made this course a lot better.
1. Versions are not up to date. In Spring Cloud, one will have to juggle around wasting hours and the reading Q&A for the obvious answer. When the answer is obvious for current learners, the course content should have been updated.
2. Though the course covers a wide variety like Feign, Ribbon, Zuul, Zipkin, it lacks in taking us deep into their usages. A very basic Hello world probem would not be enough to work in industry. One is expected to research lot more.
Otherwise, this is a nice place to start.

I spent a lot of time going through stack exchange and google to find out how to get it to work with the latest version.

results.content: Course is quite detailed and covers basic as well as advanced topics of REST and Spring cloud. Along with the default implementations like Rabbit MQ with Zipkin if some overview of actual PROD implementations like Kafka or IBM MQ was provided then that would be great and would have given an idea, of how actually working with REST/MQ/Zipkin in PROD grade applications. Other than that quite satisfied with the course.

results.content:
The course is a very good hands-on course and covers Spring Cloud and Spring boot in a comprehensive, fast paced manner.  I feel I have gained enormously from this course and will use these new skills in my day job.

One area for improvement would be a section on how all the configuration, IP address/port allocation will be implmented using a docker orchestration engine like Kubernetes.  How would Zuul/Eureka etc be configured and discovered in production.  I could follow using the localhost but could not picture how this would work in a production environments.  this would really bring the subject to life if this was included.

I would recommend this course!!!!!
results.content_html:

results.content:
Initially, when I have made my mind to purchase this course, I was not so sure about the content/quality. 
But trust me, guys, it is worth spending money on this course.

Basic concepts of micro service and RESTFul service are very well explained by Ranga.

But the beauty of the course is Spring Cloud. 
He teaches very passionately and step-by-step in the best manner.

I strongly recommend this course.

And yeah one thing more, please read all the materials uploaded on his GitHub account. It is really worth time spending.
This guy and his team have really put the effort into preparing.

So go on folks.

Have a happy learning. :)

results.content:
This course is just starting to understand the concepts of Spring Boot, Microservices, Spring cloud. It covers most of the Spring Microservice topics, but isn't in-depth.

I expect in-depth knowledge of Spring Microservices concepts. It would be better if he could explain how it works behind the scenes, why we need each component.

The structure of the source is also quite difficult to follow. If he has an overview of what will be covered in each section, recap, ...

Overall, this course is suitable for those who want to learn Spring Microservices at an overview level from development to development on Kubernetes (GKE).
results.content_html:
This course is just starting to understand the concepts of Spring Boot, Microservices, Spring cloud. It covers most of the Spring Microservice topics, but isn't in-depth.

I expect in-depth knowledge of Spring Microservices concepts. It would be better if he could explain how it works behind the scenes, why we need each component.

The structure of the source is also quite difficult to follow. If he has an overview of what will be covered in each section, recap, ...

Overall, this course is suitable for those who want to learn Spring Microservices at an overview level from development to development on Kubernetes (GKE).

The instructor is obviously well versed in the technology, but i found that the curriculum was broken down too much, which ended up causing a lot repetition and make the course feel a little slow.
 
While it was great to have some real examples to work on with the instructor, it would have been better to explain some of the theory and point out the docs and expect students to do some work on their own before looking at the solution.  This helps solidify what is being learnt.
results.content_html:

results.content:
I have a mixed opinion on this course. It was definitely good course, but a little bit uneven. I understand that technology is changing everyday and course must be updated, but adding both old and new materials to the same course do not seems like a good idea. To be able to finish course one need to go through all lectures, even for just seeing last 10 sec, to mark it as viewed. Also I think part on basic Java is not needed here, as there are similar (if not the same) course on the subject from in28minutes.
I really enjoyed microservices and docker part, and would love to see/learn more about Kubernetes, but it was already over 3 hours long so probably that was the reason. I saw a lot of added notes as a separate lectures, just to point that next video is not valid anymore. I would really expect that video lecture will be re-recorded with updated content, especially as most video are like 5 minutes long. I hope my feedback will help improve this already good course. Keep the good work, in28minutes Team :)
results.content_html:

results.content: This course is very hands-on and suitable to understand microservices and spring frameworks. A lot topics are covered to understand the basic requirements to build microservices apps. The small problem is if you have no basic knowledge of Spring Boot, it could be a bit confusing because the explanations of different annotations is very brief. However, I believe there's a separate course for that. But even if you don't have prior knowledge of Spring Boot, this course can still be followed and understood.
results.content_html: This course is very hands-on and suitable to understand microservices and spring frameworks. A lot topics are covered to understand the basic requirements to build microservices apps. The small problem is if you have no basic knowledge of Spring Boot, it could be a bit confusing because the explanations of different annotations is very brief. However, I believe there's a separate course for that. But even if you don't have prior knowledge of Spring Boot, this course can still be followed and understood.

results.content:
As a Software Engineer who works in the microservices area and faces daily challenges I would like to say that this was by far the most comprehensive course I watched on this topic. I gained different insights and I saw different approaches on how to properly configure the microservices ecosystem in order to bring it closer to a 'production ready' standard.

Thank you very much for the insights, practical parts and best practices. Keep up the good work!

P.S. As a side I would like to see this course getting an update in terms of Service Discovery, Config Server and API Gateway as they will go in maintenance mode and Spring guys will no longer contribute to the projects. With this in mind, Eureka, Ribbon and Config Server can be replaced with the Spring Cloud Consul from HashiCorp and the Zuul API Gateway with the new Spring Cloud Gateway project :D.

Peace!
results.content_html:
As a Software Engineer who works in the microservices area and faces daily challenges I would like to say that this was by far the most comprehensive course I watched on this topic. I gained different insights and I saw different approaches on how to properly configure the microservices ecosystem in order to bring it closer to a 'production ready' standard.

Thank you very much for the insights, practical parts and best practices. Keep up the good work!

P.S. As a side I would like to see this course getting an update in terms of Service Discovery, Config Server and API Gateway as they will go in maintenance mode and Spring guys will no longer contribute to the projects. With this in mind, Eureka, Ribbon and Config Server can be replaced with the Spring Cloud Consul from HashiCorp and the Zuul API Gateway with the new Spring Cloud Gateway project :D.

Peace!

results.content: This is a good 'hands-on' Spring Boot code-by-example course but its badly named - for me, not a "Masterclass" in Spring Boot; rather a set of walk-throughs of Sample Application code for Spring Boot(v2.0.0) and Spring Cloud(Finchley). Course could be much shorter with same content - a lot of time is spent watching typing with literal commentary on same; for me, whats missing for a 'MasterClass' level is due attention to the design & implementation rationales behind the inherent choices, pro's & cons, issues and constraints in technical terms. Mostly the sample apps make sense but lack technical depth. On the plus side, the Restful sample code walkthrough is a good and the Spring Cloud Microservices part, for me, a really interesting introduction to the Spring Cloud Netflix offering but more detail and an update is needed ! Finally must mention the course transcript as this really does need work too. Some examples just now...  "in this step we really collect the currency calculations with Endicott and sex in service to the country.", "Hi Cindy" and "to any component but one is adding a dependency to the pond or the X-Men." Suspect Udemy themselves have "automated" transcript generation ? (eg out of the Lecturer's control) but for a professional course it is, at times, dire, for "Crying out loud"(sic) :@P

Course could be much shorter with same content - a lot of time is spent watching typing with literal commentary on same; for me, whats missing for a 'MasterClass' level is due attention to the design & implementation rationales behind the inherent choices, pro's & cons, issues and constraints in technical terms. Mostly the sample apps make sense but lack technical depth. results.content:
Good course to start on Spring Boot Microservices.Here are few suggestions:
1. The last two sections in Appendix are redundant as we have already discussed that while learning about REST. 
2. Instead of last two sectiosn please discuss about some microservices patterns like described in this book: https://www.manning.com/books/microservices-patterns
3. Keep this video tutorial updated by adding a small video about Spring Boot Cloud Services after Netflix OSS e.g. this blog: https://dzone.com/articles/the-future-of-spring-cloud-microservices-after-net
results.content_html:
Good course to start on Spring Boot Microservices.Here are few suggestions:
1. The last two sections in Appendix are redundant as we have already discussed that while learning about REST.
2. Instead of last two sectiosn please discuss about some microservices patterns like described in this book: https://www.manning.com/books/microservices-patterns
3. Keep this video tutorial updated by adding a small video about Spring Boot Cloud Services after Netflix OSS e.g. this blog: https://dzone.com/articles/the-future-of-spring-cloud-microservices-after-net

results.content:
19.5 total hours is a click bait .
Half of the time is to cover the previous version of spring boot 
It seems Docker and Kubernetes are covered end to end,
whereas scratched the surface of microservice concepts and tools or programming
Zero videos for events and message queue
Kind of a course for spring boot beginner 

Good part:
Intro to JPA is there, it should have been core section, but it goes like a referece,
was not explained with a project,
not explained with microservice database designing, classes, annotations, how spring boot helps in there.
But I'm happy at least it's there as an appendix.

results.content:
Although I have written software professionally for over 35 years, I am new to microservices. I cannot say enough good things about this course. It is one of the best I have ever taken. "Master Microservices with Spring Boot and Spring Cloud" is an extremely well-organized course, and Ranga Karanam is an excellent instructor/presenter.

The course was worth every penny. I will definitely seek out courses from In28minutes and Ranga for my future training needs.

Thank you Ranga!

I am glad that i stumbled upon this course. 
I am a novice in Java & Spring. However, I have ample experience with .NET & OOPS. 

This course wasn't hard for me to understand the nuts & bolts of the microservices.

The author is fantastic and knowledgeable. The pace at which he takes through the course is also commendable.

This course puts them all in one place.

The course & the author deserve 10 Stars!

results.content:
Most of the instructions and information is good.  However, the placement of UPDATES is incorrect.  They should come BEFORE you need them.  For example, the POM.XML change for a dependency is deprecated/replaced by another.  After wasting some time trying to get mine to work, I find 4 lectures later where I need to change the dependency.  I do this and my original code works the first time.  Moving the update BEFORE the point where I need to use it would have saved me SEVERAL HOURS.  

When I got to SpringCloud Sleuth, NONE of the imports for AlwaysSampler would work.  A Web search shows that there may be compatibility issues with libraries.  These sections wasted a day of my time looking for an answer.  If there are known issues, you should specify EXACTLY which versions of ALL of the dependencies and tools.
results.content_html:

results.content:
The course respects the expectations and covers pretty well all the subjects described in the summary.
The lessons mix well tehory and practice, are quite fast and easy to follow and well organized in terms of subjects and lenght.
The teacher's microphone set is good and his english is understandable.
All materials and sources are easily accessible through github.
The only lessons I was expecting that misses is the integration with deployment tools like Docker, etc.
 
Some cons according to me are
- the annoying introduction and closing slides and greetings
- the presence of some hot patch slides along a lesson to overcome outdated code and lesson in case a certain technology explained has been updated.

On overall I would still strongly suggest this course
results.content_html:
The course respects the expectations and covers pretty well all the subjects described in the summary.
The lessons mix well tehory and practice, are quite fast and easy to follow and well organized in terms of subjects and lenght.

- the presence of some hot patch slides along a lesson to overcome outdated code and lesson in case a certain technology explained has been updated.

results.content:
Rating : 5

Why this rating? - The author explains in a very detailed / easy manner so that the people will be able to grasp the content easily. 

To Whom I would recommend this course ? - Target audience for this course is Spring Boot / micro services beginners. It would really help them to understand the basics. Others can use this to refresh their basics / enrich their knowledge. 

What I liked in this course ? The organized content under proper categories, short videos explaining the content.

results.content: I really enjoyed this course.  The instructor was very good in the way he slowly built our understanding of each section.  I have taken other spring courses where they stay stuck in the details and you don't really build anything useful.  I didn't have that issue in this course.  Each section had a purpose and in the end we had multiple microservices up and running both locally and via docker.  I left feeling that I learned something that I could apply in my normal job.  I recommend this course.

results.content:
For me, as a microservice newbie, this was a very good and comprehensive course to get my feet wet and get hands-on experience with microservices.

Microservices are discussed in the second part of the course. The first part was all about REST. For me the REST part could be a little bit shorter so that the Microservice part could dive a little deeper into the concepts (e.g. more info on security via the Zuul Gateway).

Nevertheless this is an excellent course for those who just stepped into the world of microservices! Excellent instructor!
results.content_html:

Nevertheless this is an excellent course for those who just stepped into the world of microservices! Excellent instructor!

results.content:
Great course, instructor is very good at explaining. But I would add an extra several hours for explaining the following missing topics:
1. Deployment of microservices to docker(or smth else). This is also very important part of microservice architecture with all the settings. Without this part course seems to be incomplete.
2. Using not in memory db but mysql or oracle(or other) as most of the real world projects are using them.
results.content_html:

results.content: It was a good course but could have been much better. In the micro services part The service name is CurrencyCalculatorService in the slides but the lecturer is using a class named CurrencyConversionService  in the code and he uses both terms interchangeably for the same service. That was creating unnecessary confusion. In the spring boot related section it would be a much clearer and a better approach if layers were arranged as controller, service, dao, and bean. Also I think the correct practice would be to use interfaces and classes implemeneting them in service and dao layers.
results.content_html: It was a good course but could have been much better. In the micro services part The service name is CurrencyCalculatorService in the slides but the lecturer is using a class named CurrencyConversionService in the code and he uses both terms interchangeably for the same service. That was creating unnecessary confusion. In the spring boot related section it would be a much clearer and a better approach if layers were arranged as controller, service, dao, and bean. Also I think the correct practice would be to use interfaces and classes implemeneting them in service and dao layers.

results.content: The instructor is really good! I was skeptical at first but my experience has been really good! He breaks down concepts into easy to understand chunks. Structure of the course is highly organized and streamlined. At no point, I felt overwhelmed with what I was presented and at the same time covering advanced stuff.  he one good thing about the instructor that others don't have is that the complexity and difficulty of concepts are increased gradually. First, the basics are covered, with detailed explanations and practical demonstrations. It helps to relate to difficult problems if you have covered the basics and trivial challenges beforehand. Awesome course! Highly recommended!
